thread.title_full: Fans pick up Mean Green safety McClain at grandfather's funeral, fly him to UNT game | Dallas Morning News

author: Brett Vito
title: Fans pick up Mean Green safety McClain at grandfather's funeral, fly him to UNT game
text:
DENTON -- Margaret Featherstone spends her days lending a hand to hundreds of North Texas student-athletes while working the front desk at Victory Hall.
There are lost keys to replace and repairs to schedule at the dorm where most of UNT's underclassman athletes live.
That's the norm.
Last week, Featherstone and her husband Tony went a whole lot further, a few hundred miles farther, to help starting safety Kishawn McClain through one of the toughest days of his life.
McClain lost Ira McClain, the grandfather who raised him since he was 7, to cancer at the age of 67 on Sept. 25.
The funeral took place in Luling last Saturday at 11 a.m., just seven hours before UNT kicked off its game against Southern Miss in Hattiesburg.
The Featherstones were planning to fly a private plane to the game, as they often do, and arranged to make an extra stop to pick up McClain on the way.
"It was a special opportunity," Tony Featherstone said. "Kishawn's a nice kid. We wanted to make sure he got to the game if we could."
The last-minute audible allowed McClain to play in a 49-14 loss and continue recovering from a tough time in his life, a process that will continue this weekend when UNT faces Portland State in its 4 p.m. homecoming game.
"It was a big conference game, and I wanted to be there for my teammates," McClain said. "I had a death in the family, but I couldn't let that stop me. If I had a chance to get to the game, I was going to do what it I could to make that work."
A private flight was the only option UNT had to get one of its top players to the game in time. UNT worked with the NCAA to make sure that no rules were broken and reimbursed the Featherstones for helping out one of its players in need.
The Featherstones were planning on taking a two-seat Grumman before upgrading to a Cessna 421, a twin engine, eight-seat plane, to make sure they had enough room for McClain to be comfortable.
The couple brought lunch and picked McClain up about 2 p.m. in Lockhart, a quick 15-mile drive from Luling.
"He didn't seem nervous about the flight," Tony Featherstone said. "He seemed preoccupied with the funeral and was focused on getting ready for the game. He was really quiet."
McClain was focused on the game and remembering his grandfather, who played a key role in his life after his father died in a car accident when he was in the second grade.
Ira McClain made his grandson egg sandwiches every morning -- one of the small memories Kishawn McClain cherishes -- and was sure to teach him about life.
"He was a good man who I respected," McClain said. "He taught me a lot, including how to be a great young man, and was always there for me. He showed me how to go down the right road in life and to be respectful of my elders and those around me."
Honoring his grandfather and being at the funeral with his family were important to McClain.
Thanks to the Featherstones, McClain had a chance to play against Southern Miss as well and finished with seven tackles, pushing his total to a team-high 42.
"None of us can imagine the roller-coaster of emotions and how hard it must have been to go out there and play hard for his teammates," UNT coach Dan McCarney said. "I'm really proud of him."
Margaret Featherstone felt the same way after lending a hand to one of the Victory Hall residents she has helped care for.
"This is Kishawn's second year here, so I feel really close to him," Margaret Featherstone said. "They are all my kiddos. I care about them all very much."
